com.dev.yvgenijsharovskij.n5kanjiandkanjistoryquiz.kanjilist

Class KanjiFragment

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.support.v4.app.Fragment
      • com.dev.yvgenijsharovskij.n5kanjiandkanjistoryquiz.kanjilist.KanjiFragment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.arch.lifecycle.LifecycleOwner, android.arch.lifecycle.ViewModelStoreOwner, android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener

    public class KanjiFragment
extends android.support.v4.app.Fragment
    KanjiFragment which appears when clicking on the RecyclerView kanji list to show the kanji info according to the clicked kanjiId.
    To prevent MOO errors, the CPU-demanding operations are run in separate threads with a static delay to match the user's average input time. Even more demanding operations are executed through the onClick event of the "Save" button.
    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Yvgenij Sharovskij
    See Also:
    Fragment

        @CallSuper
public void onDetach()
        Called when the fragment is no longer attached to its activity. This is called after onDestroy(), except in the cases where the fragment instance is retained across Activity re-creation (see setRetainInstance(boolean)), in which case it is called after onStop().

      • onCreate

        @CallSuper
public void onCreate(android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Initializes the view. Called when the activity is starting. Can call finish() from within this method, in which case onDestroy() will be immediately called without any of the rest of the activity life-cycle methods (onStart(), onResume(), onPause(), etc) executing. This method must be called from the main thread of the app.
        Derived classes must call through to the super class implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.
        Overrides:
        onCreate in class android.support.v4.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - If the activity is being re-initialized after previously being shut down then this Bundle contains the data it most recently supplied in onSaveInstanceState(Bundle). Note: Otherwise it is null.

      • onCreateView

        public android.view.View onCreateView(@NonNull
                                      android.view.LayoutInflater inflater,
                                      android.view.ViewGroup container,
                                      android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Called to have the fragment instantiate its user interface view. This is optional, and non-graphical fragments can return null (which is the default implementation). This will be called between onCreate(Bundle) and onActivityCreated(Bundle).
        Overrides:
        onCreateView in class android.support.v4.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        inflater - The LayoutInflater object that can be used to inflate any views in the fragment.
        container - If non-null, this is the parent view that the fragment's UI should be attached to. The fragment should not add the view itself, but this can be used to generate the LayoutParams of the view.
        savedInstanceState - If non-null, this fragment is being re-constructed from a previous saved state as given here.
        Returns:
        The View for the fragment's UI, or null.

      • onSaveInstanceState

        public void onSaveInstanceState(@NonNull
                                android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Called to ask the fragment to save its current dynamic state, so it can later be reconstructed in a new instance of its process. If a new instance of the fragment later needs to be created, the data placed in the Bundle here will be available in the Bundle given to onCreate(Bundle), onCreateView(LayoutInflater, ViewGroup, Bundle), and onActivityCreated(Bundle).
        Note: this method may be called at any time before onDestroy().
        Overrides:
        onSaveInstanceState in class android.support.v4.app.Fragment
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - Bundle in which to place the saved state.
